commentBody: Might as well be the first one to say it...I think they mixed up the Friday and the Saturday puzzle!

Ryan McCarty’s name strikes fear in my crossword-solving heart.  But while certainly a lot of fun to solve, this one didn’t make me sweat.  
And I’m sure I won’t be the last to say it, but any puzzle with ZONING BOARD in it makes me feel warm inside.  This puzzle’s WHO’S A GOOD BOY?
I spent several minutes looking for my typo, which of course was on the bottom row. I had left myself a note, it seems. DONT HO.

Kindness and Questions Thread

Hello, Crossword Friends! Experiment Day 2 — a thread specifically for friendly discussion. Whether you want to share what you enjoyed about today’s puzzle, ask about a clue/theme that stumped you, or just chat about something nice that happened to you today, this is meant to be a space for kindness and curiosity. I happen to be partial to fun factoids, so bring those too if you have them!

This thread isn’t meant as a statement on the rest of the comments section — just a little pocket of positivity for anyone who wants it.

I hope you all have had a great day and have a great tomorrow and a fun solve!

I was stuck for far too long on 23 down; when I finally figured it out I had to look up the first known use of “prez;” turns out it was 1686. So I can’t even grumble about the slang being a red herring.

Fun! A little chewy, but went a lot smoother than yesterday’s. I thought the longer clues/answers were great, but some of the shorter fill seemed a little too straightforward. Maybe these could be clued a bit less directly to make this feel more Saturday-y? Thanks for the puzzle!
I think this is my shortest cumulative Mon-Sat time, ever.
23D is my early leader for misdirect of the year. That was a moment of genius.
“My mother’s best friend in third grade”

I solved this one counterclockwise starting in the NW and working my way around, finishing in the NE. I was slowed a bit by DARKNSTORMY because I wanted it to be dark and stormy.  I introduced my (second) wife, a devoted wine drinker, to the joy of cocktails by getting her to try a DARKNSTORMY.  She’s moved on to cosmos and the occasional daiquiri, but still prefers to stick to wine.

Seeing BANANASEAT made me think of the stingray bike I learned to ride on. My friends and I thought we were so cool because we could pop wheelies.  These days the tricks serious bikers can do boggle the mind.  It’s probably for the best that I grew up when I did.

My RARE DISEASE for tonight had these symptoms:
Thinking it was DARK & STORMY.
Falling for the LBJ trick.
Falling for GAMBIA, (embarrassing, I know.)

But I’ve recovered now.
Saturday's  puzzle was as easy Friday's was hard for me.  Finished in a few minutes.  I'll take the win today after sweating it out yesterday!!

The puzzle was fun and surprisingly breezy for me. I enjoyed it! I'm not the first and won't be the last to say it, I'm sure, but 23D for ABE was pretty great! I also liked "Bum wrap" for DIAPER quite a bit. BANANASEAT for some nice nostalgia! A couple few things/namesI didn't know but they came pretty easily from crosses and likely language/spelling patterns. Really tried to run with ethicsBOARD at 14D but had to quickly disabuse myself of that notion. I was kind of proud of it though because I filled it in pretty quickly. It filled itself in but I've never heard of AGEMATE before. I see it's been used once before so some folks out there must use the term. Of course my all-time favorite has to be NEWT because my great-great-great-great-great-great-great grandfather was once turned into one. Here's the actual footage: https://youtu.be/fr8DIg3oHFI?si=znKnauxuM-4rOVlM

Some of the final answers, as opposed to what I initially slapped in, were quite surprising and clever.

Of course, ABE is an instant classic.

But also AMNESIAC and ONYXES gave me humorous surprises.

A fun Saturday! I really enjoy answers that can be slowly filled in using logical guesses, like BUT DAD. And it was nice for once to actually know some of trivia names like LAWSON and BARDEM, and even a tougher one like BARRY KEOGHAN which was on the tip of my brain but required mostly crosses to actually fill in.

"You don't know anything about salamanders?"
"No, I told you, I'm newt to this!"

("What about other amphibians?"
"Nope, don't have toadal recall either.")
Archaeologist here. A SHARD is a piece of glass. A piece of pottery is a SHERD. A very common mistake but the vowel is important!
no one uses asiago in place of "parmesan".
That SE corner was brutal. Great puzzle!
DATA LOSS would not be a casualty of file corruption, it would be a consequence. The casualty would be DATA.
Once again, the “tricky clues” were the most obvious ones!

TIL that in addition to Stan Lee, Brad Pitt, and Peter Falk, that ONYXES also appear in cameos.

Enjoyed the puzzle!  It brought back good memories of my first time riding a bike, followed immediately by my first time wrecking a bike.  With sparkly green paint, white handlebar grips with tassels, and a white glittering BANANASEAT, the Schwinn bike looked magnificent tumbling over my back.

I must be alone in finding this puzzle much more difficult than yesterday's.  There were some beautifully SNEAKY fills—DIAPER, after I had tried to figure out who would cover their bum with a diadem, but ABE was quick to fall.  Very pleased that MOSHPIT dropped in early, since I didn't even know what one looked like until I came to the column, but I was stuck on "phaste" for a while, even googled it (there is such a word).

All in all, a classy puzzle, Ryan McCarty. Did clues just POPUP one DARKNSTORMY night, or was it  a long time in the making?  Thanks for thinking of us, and I'm looking forward to the next one.

On 23(insert rude words here)D, with ECYCLED in place it just had to be “ike” or “dde”. For the Irish actor, well Gaelic names can be quite challenging so either kARRY or dARRY both seemed possible it was _IR that had me baffled.

I’m glad others found this easy. For me, it was like wading through sludge, for the second day in a row.

I didn’t know the actor or the drink. I’ve seen the movie, but I can never remember Best Picture winners. I had Romano instead of ASIAGO, vases instead of PEARS. And I’m still giving AGEMATE the side eye. 

A bright note: I liked BAND TSHIRTS crossing BAND BS. (Yeah, I know.)

I've never commented on the crossword before, but I must now just to say that 23D was absolutely diabolical.

What adds to the sting is that the answer flashed through my head before I dismissed it.

So much easier than yesterday!
And I feel like I’ve arrived as a puzzle solver… my immediate thought for 7A was the correct answer, rather than INNS or LODGES, irrespective of the # of letters.
Is it me or are the Minis getting harder? Like, how are Table Manners WAITERS. Can some please explain?
First run through and I only got LAWSON (Thanks Uncle Roger) and THC. The rest was manageable after looking up all the trivia questions though.

Saving oneself: CHASTE - brilliant! I chuckled sensibly when I got that 🙂 (look up "sensible chuckle" meme for an exact impression). 

I enjoyed the mental exercise of figuring out the Congolese clue. At first I was puzzled - all the the names of the countries south of DRC are 6 letters long, and I need a 7 letter answer! And that's when it dawned on me: Congolese as a person from Congo! Ergo ZAMBIAN. 

I really liked many of today's clues. I often fail to tune into the constructor's wavelength but today Mr McCarty and I seemed to be in sync.

I wouldn't have been able to fill the grid without looking up the proper nouns and trivia (including the three consecutive long entries in the middle of the across pass: the drink, the actor and the film), but I still enjoyed the experience. 

In the end I found this puzzle easier than yesterday's - on Friday I needed lookups, reveals and auto check, and today lookups sufficed.

PS. For those who remember what I wrote a few days ago - Jorge the Lab is feeling much better. As I'm writing this he's sleeping peacefully in his huge, orthopedic dog bed, with the tip of his nose and one paw sticking out of the shade of the corner of our living room into the brilliant sunshine of a cool yet clear day.

After this week i can’t wait to see Lewis’s list on Monday. 

I admit to feeling mildly annoyed by those who found yesterday and/or today easy. Sigh. As always, I thoroughly enjoyed the workouts, but solve time for me was above average on both. 

Thanks to Ryan McCarty for an impressive run of excellent, challenging puzzles.
Themeless? I suppose the swastika-esque layout is just for fun.

Strands #377
“Free for all”

Still, it was an enjoyable solve that yielded 2 musical moments for me, one somber (51 A) and one light-hearted (17 A). Warren Zevon - Please stay https://youtu.be/1-UC8eF-YP8?si=kItJ35FbxdWkSieV Michael Hurley, Unholy Modal Rounders, Jeffrey Frederick & the Clamtones - Jackknife/Red NEWT https://youtu.be/CvX2BT0iPUM?si=q3H_aGLc2ctKojYU
I’ve got to like a puzzle that includes one of my most admired people in the world.

There’s nothing cooler than a good BAND TSHIRT. I definitely wouldn’t refer to them as BAND BS! They are a great way to support your favorite artist, and considering how poor the Spotify model is for artists, they are in dire need of support these days

BANANASEAT made me laugh, and gave me hope that I might solve this Saturday puzzle without too much trouble, and so I did. A lot of unknown trivia but so thoughtfully crossed that it was not insurmountable. Ryan McCarty’s clueing is tough but fair, and always entertaining! Kudos once again!

I really wanted the plural of ONYX to be ONYCTES, but the OED doesn't even list a plural form, so I guess we're stuck with ONYXES.

Where did my first post go?

Anyone else ever stage-dived into a MOSHPIT? 

Well, my one and only dive was at a Dead Kennedys show 40-ish years ago: I lost a shoe and ended up with a bloody nose.  
BUTDAD, WHYWORRY?
I was stuck on 23D. Ike, JFK, LBJ, RMN? Almost like I wasn't alive in the 60s...
Enjoyed that!

Not an easy one for me, of course. Some look-ups and then just a lot of pondering and working the crosses. But then lots of nice moments when something finally dawned on me. That's all on me. 

Eleven debut answers - that's unusual even for a late week puzzle. Pretty impressive feat of construction.

Puzzle find today - a Monday from February 13, 2012 by Ellen Leuschner and Victor Fleming. Straightforwardly clued - just thought this was a nice reminder of variant spellings in the English language. The theme answers: 

BREADDOUGH
GARRYTRUDEAU
WAITINGFORGODOT
MARLONBRANDO
REARWINDOW

I'm done. See you tomorrow.

A few of the other proper nouns were a struggle, but never resorted to a Google SOS.  (Actually, Perplexity has become the preferred tool these days.)

Solid Saturday.

Not too hard, not too easy. I, too, found the "ABE" clue clever.

The one stumper for me was "SMH." I'd never, ever heard of this until now ("shaking my head"). 
On the other hand, I got "PDH" ("public display of affection") quickly. Is that acronym still in vogue? Perhaps the Venn diagram of those who are familiar with these phrases shows almost complete mutual exclusivity.

This had the marks of McCarty:
•	Those six-black-square stairsteps in the grid (25 of his 31 Saturdays have at least a pair of them).
•	Plenty of answers never seen in the NYT puzzle before, bringing newness into clue and answer (today there were 11).
•	A polished, junk-free filled-in grid.  I don’t take this for granted, because a junk-free 66-worder is a sign of master craftsmanship.  Low-word grids fight a constructor every step of the way; it’s a hard-won battle to come up with an answer set like this, and Ryan does it again and again.
•	Lovely quirks.  Today, a seldom-seen-in-crosswords six-letter semordnilap (DIAPER).  Also, BANANA SEATS, which triggered memories unvisited in decades.  Not to mention [“If you squint, maybe …”] for SORTA, which had me imagining tilting my head and squinting to see something a different way – and that clue just came off as perfect.

Above all, a rewarding journey requiring sweet effort and bringing a sweet payoff.  Just what I want in a Saturday puzzle.  Thank you once again, Ryan!
Maybe it's just me and being a certain age, but this week's Saturday puzzle felt more like a Friday puzzle. Great trivia and a lot of fun.

Those still-lifers really did get stereotyped. I mean, there are so many things that sit still long enough to paint them, but I bet loads of us immediately thought of pears.

I enjoyed this puzzle, and won’t be able to spell Barry’s last name in this sentence.

Had to come and say kudos for DIAPER - still giggling to myself about that one! [Bum wrap?] today and [Knight schtick?] (= "honor") yesterday are two kinda similar and truly superstar clues in my opinion!
I went straight in with Lawson, easy-peasy for a Brit, and never got truly stuck in the grid. I had no idea about BANANA SEATS so was a bit bogged down in the SW corner for a while, but it never seemed impossible.
Excellent puzzle, this is real professional standards! Many thanks Ryan!

A Master Class* in themeless construction.  Well done and thanks.  

*From Google AI Overview:  "Yes, MasterClass offers a course on crossword construction taught by renowned crossword constructor Will Shortz, the former editor of The New York Times crossword. "

Former editor?   Somebody better tell Will.
Being Irish certainly made today's puzzle easier :)

Wow. Went through all of the acrosses and only had written in SHARD. So I thought to myself, “Uh-oh, this might be one I just can’t do”. But I persevered, and little by little it came together— just like it’s supposed to! The NE corner was the last to fall (probably because I first put VISITORS for “Company”). A good challenge, thanks!

Thought at first this would be a cup of coffee, take a break and walk the dog, come back and finish over a second cup of coffee affair, but it was done by the end of the first cup. Huh!

The dog gets an extra long walk now. Enjoy the weekend, all!

Second very hard puzzle in a row for me.

Didn't know Nigella's surname. Or the drink. Or the Irish actor. Thought RAINMAN was the Best Picture, and couldn't recall the Michael Moore title. Had totally forgotten that DYLAN was awarded a Nobel. Couldn't recall the last letter in Javier's surname, though I've seen "No Country for Old Men" several times.

Yet somehow I solved this one without look-ups or errors, though it took almost 45 minutes.

Last entry was the R common to BARRY and RCCAR. Still have no idea what an RCCAR is, but BARRY/RCCAR made a lot more sense than BARMY/MCCAR.
 
"Bum wrap?" for DIAPER was clever. Don't think I've seen that one before.

All in all, an excellent Saturday puzzle!

I was feeling very smug at 43 across as an archaeologist thinking “wow, so many people are going to be confused by this one- not me though”

Oops?

McCarty is my Saturday success yardstick. I used to approach his solves with a healthy amount of trepidation, expecting a long day at it. I’ve steadily improved, and today I solved in 30! Thank you for making me a better puzzler, Mr McCarty!
Loved the 23 Down clueing:  “Prez in the 60s”.  Of course it’s LBJ, right? But then LIR for 23-across and JCYCLED at 28 across didn’t make any sense...

Couldn't do this one either! Two in a row.
The top third was ok but I didn't know any of the longer clues at all. Never mind.
Prez in the sixties was diabolical

Zipped through it with no struggle. I want my money back! Just kidding. It was fun but I prefer a Saturday puzzle that kicks my butt a little. 

Enjoy the weekend to everyone who isn't under severe weather threat and to those who are, stay safe!

I never rode a bike with a banana seat. I doubt now I ever will.
I never slam danced in a mosh pit. I doubt now I ever will.
I never bought, out of foolish extravagance, an overpriced band T-shirt. I doubt now I ever will.

Wasted youth.

OTOH, the Lions never made it to the Superbowl--with luck, they will.

A good mix of gimmes; Nigella, BARRY, DARK N STORMY, my go to cocktail if I don’t fancy a Martini and the gorgeous Sr BARDEM. Then I hit the wall of TILs, too many to mention.

Love, love the clue for DIAPERS (nappies in our neck of the woods).

Overall a chewy, rewarding Saturday. Thank you Mr McCarty.
My foot in the door was BANANASEATS. Tells you how old I am.
Loved this one! Easy for a Saturday. Banana seat, yes! The crosses really helped. I had fun today.
Given Bum, why wasn’t 10D NAPPY?
I don't appreciate when words are comprised of slang terms, like n for and. And hints in a different language? Just, why?

Like others, I had Romano cheese before ASIAGO, because I'm not so fancy. And then a dim childhood memory bubbled up of my blue Schwinn, complete with sissy bar and BANANA SEAT. Does anyone else remember sticking baseball cards in the spokes to make that motorcycle sound?

I was slightly disappointed by RARE DISEASE, because I tried to come up with an actual named disease. Lyme fit, but surely it affects more than 200K.

We did it!

Hand up for DDE and then the realization: ABE.

Thank you Ryan.

I love (actually not love) how this sometimes becomes a place for people to just boldly string out tons of answers. Am I the only one who comes here mid puzzle for a little break, read some gripes, collectively commiserate/celebrate on the day's puzzle a li'l bit before heading back to finish? Only to have a few clues ruined. Every time. Yeah, my problem for continuing to do it. But why, really? That's really what the answer key is for.

This puzzle is everything I hate about crosswords rolled into one.  Vocalizations I cannot figure out, too much trivia that I don't know, not enough wordplay.  I don't do these puzzles so I can google a bunch of stuff, believe it or not.  What a slog.  Not rewarding at all.
Same sentiment here. Much too easy. Less than my Wednesday average time for me. Enjoyable nevertheless, but I want to be a little stressed out on Saturdays.

Crossword Fans: Saturdays should be all about clever word play
NYT: Obscure proper nouns!

I literally lost count of how many naticks there are in this puzzle

Example of DATA LOSS? The modern version of Alexander Pope’s original, 1711 version of, “To Err is Humane; to Forgive, Divine.”  

I’ll see myself out.

Now they are publishing People Magazine's crosswords.
Is this level of random pop culture names and techy/Gen-Z trash slang really necessary?
I will say that some of the riddles were clever, but I have better things to do than sit around and watch TV shows and movies all day.
Can someone explain the answer to the Mini's 'Table manners?' clue? I understand the connection being made with table relating to dining out, but I just don't see 'manners' translating to 'waiters'
I didn't get it all but this was a delightful puzzle--very witty. I loved BANANASEATS and MOSHPITS. Thanks for a good Saturday solving challenge.

The Guardian has a review of a book on the history of NYC. Maybe some of you will find it interesting? Here's a link: https://www.theguardian.com/books/2025/mar/15/russell-shorto-taking-manhattan?CMP=Share_AndroidApp_Other

BUT, DAD! I know I wanted harder puzzles, but this SNEAKY?

Lol.

Haven't skimmed the comments yet.

As someone with a RARE DISEASE, that was fun(?) to see and I knew the answer almost immediately

commentBody:
Grand puzzle! BANANA SEAT BIKE alone was worth the price of admission. I had a glorious specimen back in the 70s, although because my parents bought it used, I didn’t appreciate it nearly as much as I should have. It was bright pink with a white seat with multicolored daisies. I’m sure it’s a hot commodity on some retro market, and every once in a while I’ll give it a google. No luck yet…

And thank you for making RARE DISEASE a centerpiece and raising awareness. I lost one of my dearest friends to one of these. Thinking of you, sweet Val. (P.S. Cycle for Survival is a great charity funding the search for cures.)
It took me two hours and 51 minutes with no look-ups, a glorious reprieve from the currently atrocious state of affairs. Thank you
Looks like every generational group was included...dazzling Saturday. Don't go, Ryan...give us some more puzzles! Bravo!

After yesterday this one was didn’t put up much of a fight. It’s as if they said let’s make a puzzle full of stuff that Roger will get immediately. I’d be surprised if any Brit didn’t know Nigela. My dad has had a crush on her for years and her father Nigel was Chancellor of the Exchequer, the equivalent of  Treasury secretary but much more important in the Parliamentary system. Basically number two to the PM. I love bikes and have fond memories of my banana seat version 50 years ago. I’ve spent a lot of time socializing with friends after racing sailboats so the Dark n Stormy was another gimme. I knew Barry and Bardem and having spent many childhood years in Africa it’s like the editors said let’s give Roger a record Saturday. I’m grateful as I can now enjoy the final weekend of the Six Nations Rugby.

After yesterday’s puzzle and today’s, I’m disappointed a tad. I’m not trying to be mean to the people who put their time and energy into the puzzles, but I flink (feel/think) that it’s always better when there’s a theme. I honestly didn’t understand some of the hints/answers such as ECYCLES. For a second, I thought it was somewhat of a Pig Latin theme given the Ys too. I’m so tired of seeing/typing the word, ORES at this point. Then again, perhaps it’s the atmospheric effect that’s causing some of the confusion (full blood moon, total lunar eclipse, etc…). Namaste!

So many lovely coincidings in this puzzle! SONIC* crossing with BAND* in the top right. (Yes, top right. I’m from Boston—we don’t know nothing ‘bout ordinal directions.) SEXTS and PDA at the top, shy and chaste at the bottom. AMNESIAC and DATA LOSS?! And best of all, I’M HERE at the start and DON’T GO at the end. Had me all https://youtu.be/TluCpFirXuQ. Thank you, Ryan!

Very challenging for me. I eventually got some help from Caitlin and worked all the crosses I possibly could. But my last problem spot was “Prez in the 60s” and I fell for that misdirect hook, line and sinker, because I tried both JFK and LBJ. Finally saw the light and realized it wasn’t the 1960s but the 1860s 🤦🏼‍♀️. That was very clever, I must say. Thanks for a tough but satisfying workout, Ryan McCarty.

Had CHAINGUARD instead of BANANASEAT.

Couldn't remember how to spell BARRY's last name....

Got through it anyway.

lots of smiles today: BANANA SEATS, ABE, DIAPER, and MOSH PITS stood out for me. especially BANANA SEATS, as i fondly recalled my yellow childhood bike with a banana-colored banana seat. 😉🙃

and as the mom of a kid with a RARE DISEASE, it's nice to see that mentioned--and just two weeks after rare disease day!

Even though I knew the crosses should be what they ended up being (board, disease, photo)! The sigh of relief when I let go of that word and it all fell beautifully into place!

If you don't know Barry Keoghan, he's a stunning actor.  Both "Saltburn" and "The Killing of a Sacred Deer" features him in an utterly riveting, terrifying character.

In homage to certain frequent posters here, one of whom has occasionally used golf as a comparison for crosswords:

“You call this a golf course? I’ve never once seen grass this flat in real life. It’s not what I would call real grass. And those little flags on sticks, in perfectly round holes? Pure golf-course-ese. The designers should be ashamed. And last Wednesday, when we played that other course, the rough was so long - I mean this isn’t Europe after all. How am I supposed to know if the fourth hole has a dog-leg on it?? (Pretty windy today - and my knee is sore - I hate this course.) And how about those snooty members of the club who suggest we practice more? They never met a gold course they didn’t enjoy. Why do they love golf so much?

Same time tomorrow for another round?”

I don’t know if this applies to Danielle specifically, but in general, there is a huge Dunning-Kruger kinda thing going on in this comments section, which IMO accounts for at least 90% of the testy exchanges.

That is, lots of newer solvers get good at solving easy puzzles pretty quickly, and come to view themselves as having attained intermediate/strong crossword-solving skills. At that point, they start passing judgment on “bad” clues (or even entire puzzles), which are almost always perfectly fine, but simply didn’t click for them in the way they’ve come to expect.

What they don’t realize is that they have a *long* way to go on the crossword puzzle learning curve — and that, should they continue to progress along that curve, their feelings about more challenging puzzles/clues will change drastically (i.e. to the point of completely invalidating most of their earlier complaints/criticisms).

Finally, this pattern has gotta be badly exacerbated by the general trend toward increasingly easy late-week puzzles — if the Friday and Saturday puzzles from 10-25 years ago were still being published, I suspect most people in the cohort described above would be much quicker to recognize the scale of the delta between their present skill level and the challenge presented by harder puzzles.

It’s truly a tale of two comments sections…

@Shrike 

First and foremost, let's get this out of the way: 
 I didn't miss an opportunity to learn an interesting fact because I already knew that fact.

The complaint that it was a "mistake" in the puzzle, as Barry pointed out, was itself a mistake.

A clue is correct when it's "technically correct", which is of course the best kind of correct.  This is a basic tenet of crosswords, one that you seem to push back on.

Archeologists say "sherd"; the rest of the world says SHARD (most of the time).  (And they're actually two variants of the same word, derived from an old English word containing both the e and the a.) 

Usage dictates correctness; that's an immutable rule of language.  The Lego company says, "Call our bricks Lego in the plural."  The rest of the English-speaking world (or at least, Americans) call the Legos.  This can't be wrong, no matter how much the company protests.

Life goes on.

Using words to mean various things, or various words to mean the same thing, is a hallmark of language, one that distinguishes it from science and mathematics.

@Shrike It is important to understand that in crossword clues and answers, a word may be used in other than its primary definition, and if it is, it is likely to be an intentional misdirection. This is considered a feature, not a flaw, even though some people do not like it. As long as the word in question meets **any** dictionary definition, there is no basis for the accusation of an error. In this case, see definition 3: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/casualty And before you say "Well, that's just Merrriam-Webster," the other online dictionaries agree. You might say that "casualty" in this definition is not used in "careful usage," but that's a value judgment. It's interesting that this is the second most recommended comment so far, and the top one is also based on an erroneous gotcha, the one about "sherd" vs. SHARD. I was strangely pleased when I had the top comment several times in the past week or so, but I now realize that getting recommendations really doesn't prove anything.

I'm going to elaborate on this a bit, since you're not a native speaker of English.

"Man" used as a verb, probably came from naval usage. You could have people manning the bilge pumps on a sailing ship, manning the anti-aircraft guns on a destroyer, or manning the wheel. There's a little flavor of crisis management here; each person at their station, doing their part. By extension, you can apply it to less risky situations...cashiers manning their registers during a busy period, for example.

Or further extending it, it can just mean being at your work station and doing your job. You could, for example, be dressed in a neat suit and a bow tie on a slow day at a hotel, manning the concierge's desk.

So even if the fan base was modest, there was something coming in to offset the costs of recording etc. Nowadays with most people streaming, that same fan would have to listen to the song at least 300-400 times for the artist to make close to $1 which, unless they are a super fan and listening daily, could take years (or never happen). And then on Spotify, the artist still may not get anything for their music if the track has under 1K streams in the last 12 months because of them changing their payouts last year. There are ways of increasing stream counts via getting on playlists, but since that is mostly passive listening, it unfortunately doesn’t do much to help build a fan base that will support the artist via other means.

@Ms. Billie M. Spaight 

No, Pope means human, as in, “belonging to the human race,” but he’s using the 1711 spelling. 

From the 1661 edition of Blount’s Glossographia anglicana nova: “Humane: (Lat.) belonging to Mankind ; also Courteous, Affable.” (No entry for ‘human.’)

From the 1720 edition of Phillips’s New World Dictionary: “(Lat.) belonging to Mankind, also mild, kind, gentle, courteous, friendly, obliging.” (Still no entry for human, though Phillips expands on Blount a bit in his quest to be seen as a compiler, and not an out-and-out plagiarist, but he still doesn’t have an entry for ‘human.’)

And here, finally, we have Samuel Johnson’s  Dictionary of the English language listing both in 1756 (omitting citations):

“HUMAN. adj. 1. Having the qualities of a man.
2. Belonging to man. 

HUMANE, adj. Kind; civil benevolent; good-natured.”
. . . she explained as humanely  as is humanly possible.

commentBody:
@Hardroch 

Ooh, that is close! Alas, grandchildren are not imminent; gen Z sons are up to a lot, except for settling down.:-)

@G 

I feel your pain. I, too, never had a banana seat. Or tasseled handlebars. My dad would not buy us new bikes, but found and rebuilt solid (heavy) one-speed WWII bikes. Reasoning we could not tear them up. 

We had them in graduated sizes, from a 14" frame all the way to adult. As the four of us grew, we moved up through the sizes, irrespective of whether the frames were male or female (had a crossbar or not). I, unfortunately, never made it to the top of the line because my brothers passed me.

My dad would occasionally pull them apart down to the ball bearings and rebuild them. I remember sitting on the ground next to him, using an old toothbrush to clean the ball bearings after they had been soaking in turpentine. 

After the neighborhood kids tore up their bikes, they would borrow ours--even though they were painted a distinctive yellow we called "yaller," so that my dad could spot them as soon as he turned in to our subdivision.

@Lynn 

Wow, so many thoughts come to mind! How much effort your father put into rebuilding those bicycles. How heavy they must have been! (And flat the subdivision? I grew up on a hill...) Which also calls to mind the phalanxes of modern rental bikes, with their boxy parts both theft-resistant and repair minimizing. Yaller yellow, huh? I hope it was a color you could enjoy!
